Jacqueline Netter Guerroudj came to teach in Algeria in 1948 and joined the Algerian Com- munist Party shortly afterwards. She married Djilali Guerroudj: together they fought for Algerian independence until their arrests in January 1957. They were sentenced to death but pardoned thanks to an intense campaign in France on their behalf, led by such intellectuals as Simone de Beauvoir, Jean-Marie Domenach, Michel Leiris, Jean-Paul Sartre, François Mauriac, and Paul Ricoeur. Their partner Abderrahmane Taleb was executed. Jacqueline Guerroudj remained with the FLN until 1965. She still lives in Algeria. See her autobio- graphical work Des douars et des prisons (Algiers: Editions Bouchene, 1993).
"Nationalité Algérienne," Les Temps Modernes nos. 432-33 (July-August 1982): 296.
